item.title: About Me
item.description: Joshua Pughe-Sanford is a Flatiron Research Fellow in the Center for Computational Neuroscience (CCN). They works on a dynamical systems framework of neurons, with a particular focus on the reconstruction of dynamics from sparse measurements, identification of independently evolving subsystems, and symmetry reduction. Josh recently graduated from Georgia Tech with a Ph.D. in physics and an M.S. in mathematics. Their dissertation explored extending the dynamical systems theory of Axiom-A chaos to fluid turbulence.

item.title: Showcase
item.description:
Talks

  • Heteroclinic Connections as Predictors of Extreme Events in Weakly Turbulent Flow, DFD Seattle 2019. (Slides / Talk)

  • Numerical Methods for Determining the Walk Dimension of Quantum Walks, Emory University 2017.

Publications

  • S. Boettcher, J. Pughe-Sanford (2017). Renormalization of Discrete-Time Quantum Walks with non-Grover Coins. Journal of Statistical Mechanics, 2018(3).

  • J. Pughe-Sanford (2017). Properties of Quantum Walks within Various One Dimensional Media. Honors Thesis.

Unpublished Work

  • J. Pughe-Sanford (2017). Experimentally Validating Bell’s Theorem.

  • J. Pughe-Sanford (2016). Modeling the Lorenz Equation on an Electrical Circuit.
